intro.text:
“Junior” clothing lines often channel this interest with youthful styles that fit tweens and teens as they grow.

The median 11-year-old can typically wear a size Medium in the Juniors section.

intro.sizeBands: XXS, XS, S, M, L, XL, XXL
intro.text:
But not all tweens wear the same size.

If we were to look at a sample of all 10- and 11-year-old girls in the U.S., here are the Juniors sizes that match up with their body measurements.

Notice that there are sizes available for most girls in this age group.

intro.sizeBands: XXS, XS, S, M, L, XL, XXL
intro.text: By age 15, most girls have gone through growth spurts and puberty, and they’ve reached their adult height. Many have started to outgrow the Junior size section.

intro.sizeBands: XXS, XS, S, M, L, XL, XXL
intro.text:
If they tried wearing clothes made for adult women, here are the sizes that would generally fit most 14- and 15-year-olds.

It’s unlikely that each size will fit every teen perfectly (more on that later), however this marks an important turning point.

intro.sizeBands: XXS, XS, S, M, L, XL, XXL
intro.text: This will be the first time that nearly every girl their age will have women’s sizes available that are within an inch of their waistline measurements…

intro.sizeBands: XXS, XS, S, M, L, XL, XXL
intro.text: ...this will also likely be the last time this ever happens in their lifetimes.

intro.sizeBands: XXS, XS, S, M, L, XL, XXL
intro.text: By their 20s, a size Medium will no longer reflect the median or average woman’s waistline.

Instead, the median 20-something fits a size 14.

This places them in the middle of what’s sometimes called the “mid-size gap” — a murky space that varies from brand to brand in determining where “regular-” or “straight-size” clothing lines end, and separate “plus-size” ranges begin.

Sizing options are even worse when you look at all adult women over the age of 20.

The median woman in the U.S. fits around a size 18 based on their waistline measurement.

Only a small portion of brands carry sizes larger than a size 16.

That leaves nearly three-quarters of all women without sizing options at all

introText: Like many girls her age, she loves to keep up with the latest fashion trends and explore new ways to express herself.

titlePage.title: Sized Out
titlePage.subtitle: What happens when women’s clothing sizes fit more teens than adults

paragraphs.0: Most adult women do not look like teen girls — nor should they.
paragraphs.1: As they age and reach major life milestones in adulthood — perhaps graduation, marriage, having kids, or advancing in their career — their bodies continue to develop and change.
paragraphs.2: But for most women as they progress through life, the range of accessible clothing options will become smaller and smaller. Many, if not most, will have no available sizing options at all.

section2.subhed: This has been a problem for a very, very long time
section2.text:
Many people are likely all-too familiar with the ego-deflating experience of trying on a pair of pants that they expected to fit — but they don’t.

TKMany factors determine “good” fit

  • Waistline is one of several important measurements
  • Personal preferences vary on tight-vs loose-fitting clothes
  • Boxy styles & stretch fabrics give more wiggle room to squeeze into smaller sizes

For years, many have blamed sizing inconsistencies on so-called “vanity sizing,” a practice that assumes women are more likely to buy clothes labeled as sizes that are smaller than they actually are.

Indeed, vanity sizing has undoubtedly shifted how we label each size. But there’s more to the story.

vanitySizing.text:
Here is what standard sizes looked like in 1995.

There was 12.5” separating the smallest size 2 (24”) and the largest size 20 (36.5”).

Today, that gap is 15.2” between the smallest size 00 (25.38”) and the largest size (40”). While additional sizes for 00 and 0 were added in the early 2000s, all waistline measurements were larger regardless of size.
Notice how in 1995 a 27-inch waist was considered a size 8 — in 2021 it was between sizes 2 and 4 — and today’s size 8 is 2.5 inches bigger.

Waistlines in the U.S. have also increased since the mid-90s.

Between 1988 and 1994, the average woman’s waistline was 34.88 inches. By 2018, it was 38.74 inches
In both cases, both 30 years ago and today, the median waistline roughly lined up with the size 18 that was available at that time (if at all).

ASTMtransition.subhed: Mass-produced clothes don’t fit every body
ASTMtransition.text:
Just because one particular size may fit at a person’s waistline, that doesn’t mean the overall garment will fit.

An organization called ASTM International has tried to standardize apparel with a universal size chart that is updated every decade or so. Brands and manufacturers are meant to use this sizing system as a template to develop their unique size ranges.

With each update, however, the ASTM sizes have continued to skew toward the smallest women, leaving out nearly half of the population

In many ways, this has been intentional.

ASTM has said itself that it’s not trying to develop a system that accurately reflects modern demographics in America.

Instead, the system is just as much tailored to conventional beauty standards and what clothing brands consider to be their ideal customer.

proportions.text:
If we were to take the waist and hip measurements of the median woman in the U.S., here’s a broad look at what those proportions would look like.

Notice there’s just over a 4” difference between her waist and hip measurements.

Let’s say that our typical adult woman goes shopping at J.Crew.

If she were to try on a pair of pants that fit her waist, she could try and squeeze into a size 18, which is within ¾” of her measurements.

Doing so, however, would mean the pants were made for someone with hips that are roughly 6 inches larger than hers.

If the median American woman were to prioritize finding pants that are fitted around her backside, she would have the opposite problem as before.

Here, a size 12 would fit her hips best, but then the waist would be too small by more than 6 inches.

J.Crew is hardly an outlier.

The foundation for most — if not all — mainstream fashion brands is based on an hourglass silhouette.

For brands like J.Crew, Anthropologie, Ralph Lauren, Aritizia, and more, that means a 10-inch difference between the waist and hip from the biggest size to the smallest size.
Surprisingly, it’s not uncommon for all sizes to have the exact same hourglass proportions.

history.text: In 1941, the U.S. government set out to standardize clothing sizes for women. The garment- and pattern-making industry had exploded following the industrial revolution, but the approach to sizing was less a science and more trial-and-error, researchers noted. They found wide variations in garment sizes made by different manufacturers. Clothing alterations often cost an additional 25% on top of the original sale price. Clothes that didn’t fit or couldn’t be altered were frequently returned to the store, at a high cost to all parties involved. “This means a loss of money and good will to the retailer and annoyance and waste of time to the woman purchaser,” wrote the report’s chief researcher, Ruth O’Brien. Sound familiar? Over 85 years later, and many of those same problems and annoyances are just as true, if not worse today. The landmark study set in motion the foundation of our modern sizing system that is inherently skewed by age and race. The 1941 study that only captured the body measurements of white, mostly young, middle class women from urban areas within just a handful of states. And while it was likely the first to even attempt to gather a broad dataset of body measurements, it created a system that perpetuated the conventional beauty standards of young, white bodies. This matters because we know that age and genetics factor quite a bit into our shape and body proportions. Because of these biases, the blueprint for nearly every piece of women’s clothing is based on an hourglass silhouette.

textA.value: In 1941, the U.S. government set out to standardize clothing sizes for women. The garment- and pattern-making industry had exploded following the industrial revolution, but the approach to sizing was less a science and more trial-and-error, researchers noted. They found wide variations in garment sizes made by different manufacturers. Clothing alterations often cost an additional 25% on top of the original sale price. Clothes that didn’t fit or couldn’t be altered were frequently returned to the store, at a high cost to all parties involved.
“This means a loss of money and good will to the retailer and annoyance and waste of time to the woman purchaser,” wrote the report’s chief researcher, Ruth O’Brien.

textB.value: Over 85 years later, and many of those same problems and annoyances are just as true, if not worse today.

The landmark study set in motion the foundation of our modern sizing system that is inherently skewed by age and race. The 1941 study that only captured the body measurements of white, mostly young, middle class women from urban areas within just a handful of states. And while it was likely the first to even attempt to gather a broad dataset of body measurements, it created a system that perpetuated the conventional beauty standards of young, white bodies. This matters because we know that age and genetics factor quite a bit into our shape and body proportions.
Because of these biases, the blueprint for nearly every piece of women’s clothing is based on an hourglass silhouette.

sizeCharts.text: Many prominent (particularly high-end) brands do not carry sizes higher than a size 14 or 16. Smaller than both the average woman’s waistline of 37.68” and ASTM guides.
Some brands carry extended options within their “Regular” or “Straight” size ranges that extend beyond the median.
While others have a “Plus” size range that is kept separate, often with simpler styles that differ from other straight size collections.
